So after 500 hours in this game and reaching end game items I feel like I can write a objective and well-informed review about the game.

Overall, I don't recommend it.
However, if you want to play with friends, say you buy a 4-pack (on sale, of course) and you stay off the dlc's, it is a nice purchase. Playing the game all the way up to lvl 70 pre-nightmare mode, the game is lots of fun and very unique. It is after that point where it just isn't worth it.

The person in charge of development got really greedy with the game and started releasing lots of dlc's, each one containing either one hero or one map. Which means you have to spend a lot of money to get the full experience of the late game.

On top of that, nightmare mode is such a cliff that you are pretty much forced to buy the summoner and EV dlcs in order to progress through it, as well as farm for hours in order to get decent items. The big flaw in the game is that it relies on RGN; the items rely on stats that are randomly generated. And instead of fixing this system, the devs decided to just give you more items so hopefully you eventually get a lucky drop. Most of the items generated are either missing key stats, or have negative values on them thus reducing your chances of getting anything decent.

The trading community is slowly dying if not dead, since most good players decided to move onto better games.
So like I said, I enjoyed the first few hours pre nightmare, but after that it just isn't worth your time or money.

reviewText:
No, I would not recommend this game to anyone, for any reason. At the tail end of of almost a thousand hours, and after careful deliberation, I cannot find anything redeeming in Dungeon Defenders. Not its single-player, not it's multi-player, certainly not its Tower Defense, not its loot mechanics, and, most assuredly, not its community. The whole Dungeon Defenders experience, from the first achievement for simply following a tutorial, to the last achievement in killing four giant snowmen and an alcoholic Santa Claus, is garbage.

Let me get this out of the way – The original thirteen maps of Dungeon Defenders and the original four classes, they're fine. The original, vanilla Dungeon Defenders experience, although simplistic, has a very clear and defined progression. Your four classes – the Apprentice, the Squire, the Huntress, and the Monk – are fairly well balanced for both solo play and multiplayer, and because you can swap characters during maps in solo play, you can make doubly strong defense setups with combinations from those four classes. It is entirely possible, with good tower strategies, to go from the beginning of the game to the end of the game – that is, from Deeper Well to Glitterhelm Caverns - all on the same difficulty with hardly any farming, up to the tail end of Insane difficulty. The original Dungeon Defenders, simplistic it may be, is roughly fifty hours of a tight tower defense experience with a lot of experimentation possible within it.

Enter Nightmare. Enter spiders, enter djinns, and enter sharkens. Which, alright, those aren't bad. These are enemies that are designed to target and disrupt your defenses so that you'd have to reconsider your defense setups. Up to Insane, you weren't really punished for not using all four classes, so Nightmare is the point where the game decides to kick you around a bit and force you to play it better. So, you'll go back and level up a new class to use in conjunction with your usual class and take another crack at it.

So with a format like this, how did this game get screwed so badly?

DLC upon DLC happened, ramping the game's difficulty by numbers up faster than players could keep up with it. You could gotten away with playing with lower stats if it weren't for the Sky City patch that introduced Goblin Copters. Goblin Copters dropping their buffed up Ogres on your defenses alone increased the minimum stat requirements for maps by quite a bit. After that, maps began spamming Ogres ad nauseum just as a difficulty supplement rather than having actual difficulty within the map's designs. Suddenly, people couldn't keep up with the game's difficulty without farming late waves of Survival mode for incrementally better gear. But the random number generator was bugged, so it wasn't giving out progressively stronger gear as often as it should have been. And so, people spent more time farming in the game than they do actually progressing in it.

Entire class DLCs – The Series EV, the Jester, and the Summoner – were released just to keep the game possible to beat, rather than to supplement the game with new and interesting ways to play it. By the real end of the game, those classes are a requirement to succeed. If you favored the Squire or the Apprentice when you began playing the game, they are going to gather dust in your character roster because the real end of the game doesn't even have actual tower defense in the way that the very first thirteen maps do.

Let's also keep in mind that most of the DLC is outsourced to the winners of map contests held by Trendy on their official Dungeon Defenders forums (that unnavigable mess) and other DLCs are very clearly sourced to a different set of developers from the initial game. What this means is that there's a ton of maps in the game that have an inconsistent graphical quality and difficulty – difficulty, by the way, at this point rarely amounts to anything more than using the same three correct classes over and over in the correct spots with no room for experimentation. Then, those maps take anywhere from twenty to forty minutes at a time because of rapidly inflating mob counts per wave.

Look, I get that a difficulty name like “Nightmare” means, okay, the game is going to be hard now, and that naturally does mean you're going to need higher stats to beat older maps, as well as be pretty damn tough in order to meet the requirements of the endgame. That's standard difficulty in game design. And Dungeon Defenders does that! Initially, Nightmare mode challenges your perception of building maps to compensate for spiders dropping in behind your defenses, sharkens who can charge in and completely push them out of the way, and djinns who can just outright destroy them.

But, the metagame changed. Suddenly, the solution is always a line of summons on a buff beam underneath a stack of auras. Every special mob and the threat presents is handled by that solution alone. And with that one-size fits all solution, it becomes the only solution that maps are designed around. Difficulty is reduced to a stat requirement on a board that says, “Here. This is how difficult it is, this is what kind of numbers you need to scrape by on the skin of your teeth with, this is what kind of numbers you need to beat it comfortably and farm it, and this is what kind of super low number you can beat it with to stroke your ePeen. These are the points you need to put on the DLC Summoner, the DLC Series EV, the Monk, and the Huntress. Haha, what? Apprentice and Squire? Those aren't relevant.” And that says nothing of building a character for tackling bosses.

Once you get somewhere new in Dungeon Defenders, get comfortable. You're gonna be there for a while, until you get lucky. By a Trendy developer's own admission, the stats on drops are bugged so that they rollover – become worse than they should be when they're spawned – and thus the progression is more restrictive than it was ever intended to be. And indeed, DLC was released to try and get around that too. But DLC can't fix a fundamentally broken game, and in fact, it actually broke it more, because the loot coming out of it was too god, so it came out gimped, per that bug.

It is actually to the point where, in order to maximize your chances of getting loot that will give you better stats, and thus, help you move forward, an X-Box controller emulator was devised in order to take advantage of splitscreen. This is so you can have four chances at a map's rewards, rather than just the one, for your thirty minute run of what-the-hell-ever map. And I expect that this tool was only ever intended for the obsessive munchkin crowd, but it rapidly turned into a requirement to proceed at all in the game.

This is not tower defense. This is just farming and reaping the rewards of poor soil.

So, now that you understand what a majority of Dungeon Defenders is, I want you to take a look at the Most Helpful (All Time) reviews here on Steam for this game. Most of them are from people with people whose hours number in the multiple thousands. I hope that at least explaining the arbitrary farming puts into context those hours.

Dungeon Defenders, even with all its DLC, does not have nearly enough content to justify those lengths of time, or, hell, even my own, and by its own design, it's not a game I could recommend to anyone.

It's a bad game.

reviewText:
Magic towers? Check. Defensive auras? Check. Bombs? Check. Barriers? Check. Huge weapons? Check. Hordes of monsters waiting patiently behind strategically placed doors until players are ready? Check! Action RPG and tower defence hybrid Dungeon Defenders brings all those things to the table, plus more. It may not be the sharpest looking, musically creative, or thoughtful game out there, but it makes up for all of that by just being a lot of fun.

Leaving their kids behind, the four legendary heroes of Etheria have set out to vanquish evil, loot caves and, if they're like most heroes, probably spend a fair bit of time in the local tavern. Their children, who had been content to stay behind and dream of adventure, accidently unleash an ancient power and soon find their castle surrounded by monsters. Crazy kids. True to their heritage, the young warriors take up their weapons and prepare to defend their home. The story is cute, but aside from a few brief cutscenes, largely irrelevant.

The premise of Dungeon Defenders is simple: protect your crystal against hordes of monsters by building towers. There are four classes you can choose to play: the apprentice, who summons magic-shooting towers; the squire, who builds fortifications and medieval-style weaponry; the huntress, who lays traps and snares; and the monk, who can create auras to aid friends and hinder foes. Each class is diverse in their skills and abilities, and can be further customised each time they level up by assigning points to them, their towers, or both. In addition, there is a plethora of loot dropped each level that can give your heroes an edge in a fight. Even pets can be obtained to help you out!

As you level up, new skill points are not your only advantage. All fortifications you build require mana for construction, which you can collect from treasure chests or fallen foes. Each time you level up, your maximum mana capacity increases. This allows you to store mana for repairs, upgrades and special class skills. Unfortunately, not all classes are created equal. As a team of four, the apprentice, squire, huntress and monk are a near unstoppable force of perfect complementary skills. Working individually, however, is a far different story. The apprentice and squire can hold their own, but if you prefer to play solo, you can say goodbye to much success with either the huntress or monk.

There are 13 campaign maps in total (plus more through paid DLC), and each requires a new strategy. Early maps tend to have few chokepoints and only one crystal to defend, while later maps are a veritable maze of potential enemy paths, and may have up to four separate crystals. Maps can support up to four players (six on some of the DLC maps), and enemy health is scaled accordingly. As a result, you can tackle missions alone or online with friends and enjoy a challenge either way.

Each set of maps has a unique feel. There are maps set inside servants' quarters, the throne room and the forge, while later challenges take you outside to the gardens or onto the roof. The cartoony, cel-shaded graphics are a delight and suit the light tone of the game well. Bright green gardens on one map are an excellent contrast to the dreary, rain-splattered turrets of another, and the diverse designs really set the maps apart from one another. Character faces look a little odd, but heroes are otherwise equally attractive; especially the apprentice, whose face is hidden beneath his pointy wizard hat. Unfortunately, different genders for each hero are only available as paid DLC. Bummer.

Between maps, you return to your own special tavern, in which you can buy and sell equipment, organise your inventory or admire any achievements you earned, which take physical form as trophies. You visit the tavern of whoever is hosting the current game, which means you can show off to your friends, too! A word of warning though: in-game trophies can be earned in any mode, but achievements can only be completed through ranked online play. Annoying, but a necessary precaution considering the game is open to modding in offline or non-ranked play.

Clearing all maps on medium takes around 15 hours, but there are three harder difficulties available (Hard, Insane, and Nightmare), complete with more powerful loot. Extra challenges are provided that mix things up too, such as a map where the crystal changes locations or where roles are reversed and you go on the attack. Many of these require multiple players though, so it's far more enjoyable if you can play with your friends.

Online play functions amiably, but some further polish would have been beneficial. Joining or creating a game is easy enough, but at higher levels, I was often kicked the second I set foot into a game without explanation. Unlike many other multiplayer games, there is no voting system to kick people, so if one person has a problem with you, you're gone. There's no loot designation system either, so it's a free-for-all on the best drops. That said, most players are relatively blasé about gear and leave it alone to be auto-sold at the end of the round. On the bright side, the game natively supports voice chat.

I may have initially been disappointed by the focus on online play, but these fears quickly passed as I discovered what an enjoyable game Dungeon Defenders is. 13 maps with 15-20 hours of play is a considerable amount of initial content, but the extra challenges and loot-hunting are what will keep you coming back. Working out strategies and tower placement is a great fun, and finally succeeding in your strategy is immensely satisfying. Some of the online features are a little rough, but if you enjoy a good tower defence game, then you should not miss this one.

Highly Recommended

reviewText:
I should love this game.
A tower defence game with heavy roleplaying elements, vibrant colours and plenty of different strategies to choose from.

The core gameplay actually really speaks to me too. You control your hero, selected from 4 different types (or more, we'll get into that) and defend the Eternia Crystals using both an assortment of weapons and summoned magical defences.
There are wizards that summon elemental towers, knights that summon medieval fortifications and siege weapons, monks that work with auras and hunters that employ traps.
All of these feel different and entertaining, and for a first impression this game made a great one.
The further you get from this core gameplay though, the bleaker things start to look.

Your hero levels up by defeating enemies and surviving waves (or rather, having the crystal survive waves. Your hero just respawns if he/she dies), and gets a skill point or two to invest into either personal statistics like health or damage or choose to increase similar values on their summoned defences. This means that you have to choose how to balance things between your hero and your defences.
Higher levels will also unlock access to better (randomly generated, typical RPG fare) loot, new defences and 2 special skills.

Spare mana from levels, which is there used to summon, repair and upgrade defences, heal the player and use special skills, is given to the player and is then used to buy items from the shop in the tavern (hub level) or upgrade existing items. Both of these take a ton of mana, far more than you'll get just by progressing through the game normally. You'll need to grind a lot to afford your first pet, or max out even the shoddy level 1 gloves you're likely to have picked up during the opening level.

Then there are 25 pieces of DLC for this game, total value ~5x times the cost of the base game that add new levels, new costumes and new heroes (some actually new ones but mostly gender-swapped reskins of the original 4 classes).
There are three modes of playing this game, locally, online using the Steam system and 'Ranked' using Trendy's own in-house system. Ranked is the only way to earn achievements, and is completely separate from the rest of the game (characters, campaign progress, even camera settings) which pretty much negates all the neat Steam workshop stuff that's out there since everybody is playing Ranked instead.

I first bought and played this game on XBox Live Arcade, which was almost entirely neglected by the development team. Not only did they not get most of the DLC, they were also passed over on actual game updates, including patches and bug fixes. For example, to this day the first Apprentice tower has a hard cap on its firing speed that makes it utterly useless for higher level players.

More recently a semi-sequel came out, Dungeon Defenders Eternity, which repackaged all of the original content into a shiny new package... and expected people to just buy it again. Worse yet, that game has since been abandoned and just half-heartedly (and looking at the community comments, also just incompletely) compensated the disappointed players by giving them a free copy of Dungeon Defenders.

I don't normally bother with things like that in a review, but their business practices really are abysmal, and the game would need to be a hell of a lot better for me to excuse them.
So now there's an Early Access sequel in the works, which looks to add even more weird design choices and problems and I'm just done with all of it.
Whatever is going wrong at Trendy Entertainment is going very wrong and I recommend everybody that will listen to watch it from a safe distance and not buy their games, including this one.

Maybe get Defender's Quest instead, since that's also a tower defence rpg hybrid and it's actually good

Gameplay with KBM works pretty well, especially once you learn the hotkeys, but all text and menus are blown up HUGE on screen, obscuring the game ... a hallmark of a mediocre port from the land of consoles.

Proceed with low expectations.

reviewText:
Tower defense mixed with third person hack and slash.  Awesome game over all.

The game is great for at least 40 hours of game play if not more even if you aren't being obessive about upgrades and loot drops.  I ended up playing this single player a great deal of time when I first got it and even before I burned out I played mostly single player, that being said it's great fun to get a group of friends together and run over hoards of goblins and making strategies that fail, bearly work, or are overly powerful.  Expirmentation and variation are great.

The early game and mid game are great for casual gamers.  Some thing to pick up and go.  Hammer out the easy/normal/hard difficulties for fun, leveling up characters and weapons has a fairly decent curve and is enjoyable for most skill levels.  It can be a heck of a challenge for those who try to jump into hard content from a low level or a smooth ride for those who just progress naturally.

The late game is a bit tedious... I'm talking after you beat the normal difficulties and normal maps.  When you get into the advanced content it gets to be a giant pain in the butt to grind for good weapons and armor, trading is a nightmare and the amount of mana to upgrade anything is absolutly insane.  Playing with people at the higher levels is also very aggrivating.  The late game was designed to be very hard, and it is.  It's also for only for the stout hearted.

All of that being said I highly recommend picking up this game on sale or not.  If you like tower defense or hack n' slash you'll probably like this game.  The late game shouldn't put you off because you can easily put in 40 hours or more before you get to late game content if you're just looking for a game to enjoy.

reviewText:
This game was probably the most value for money purchase I have ever made. I have sunk countless hours into this game (I lied.. steam counted 737..) and it has provided me with hours of fun, a great community and a lot of interesting gameplay. The game itself is a 3rd person tower defence game with an rpg element to it. Your hero levels up and gets new items that drop from the monsters you kill. The loot is randomly generated which in itself has a good and a bad side. The good side being BAJILLIONS of armor/weapon variants. The down side is that getting good quality loot and more importantly loot that you need and are looking for is very difficult, especially when you get to the higher rarity armor and weapon types. This can make the game very grindy and if doing levels over and over again, perfecting your layout and gameplan isn't for you then Dungeon Defenders isn't for you, at least not if you want to be the very best like no one ever was..

That being said there are a lot of levels, challenges, maps and various modes to play giving the game enough variety and interesting gameplay to warrent anyone playing it for the price. There are some big flaws with the game. The prime of these boil down to two things; There is a lot of DLC, and I do mean a lot of it, and the game is very easy to hack. Now the DLC aspect of the game isn't too terrible. There is a lot of it but a lot of it is cosmetic and almost all of them are cheap. Now the hacking is an actual problem. The game is very easy to hack and hence hackers are prominent in the community, even in the online play. Trendy tries to monitor and ban hackers but it is a bit out of their control. If you are the kind of person who likes to play by themselves (which you totally can) then this won't affect you at all. If you want to play online with others then I suggest using the forums and getting to know a few people who play the game (or get your friends to play with you). Having people you regularly play with ensures a nicer experience then trying to adapt to pub games and risk having your experience ruined by hackers.

With all this in mind I still feel like Dungeon Defenders was a great purchase and a great experience. reviewText:
Yep, aware this game is almost 3 years old:)) But I'm gonna write a review anyway! Dungeon Defenders is a choice game:) Recommend? Certainly yes. If hybrid hack and slash /tower defense is your thing then this is for you. If its not, get it any way. You'll still have a blast, especially if you play with mates. I, and everyone I have played with, have had a lot of fun with this game.

The following is a list of what I consider pros, cons, and things I am on the fence about . Pros being things i liked (of course), cons being things that annoy me, and 'on the fence' being things that are kinda  'hmmm...yeah, mehh' but not enough to sway my opinion of the game. And yes, my opinion is subjective:) Here we go:

Pros:
* Multiple characters to choose from with distinct abilities. Allows for a variety of play styles. You'll find a character who has a play style that you like and feel 'at home' with.
* Frequent character 'level ups'. Creates a good sense of character progression and hey,  we all love becoming more awesome:)
*'Level Ups' are well balanced. 'Level ups' on both equipment and characters feel like they are a real choice that impacts your play. But not game changing enough that you 'gimp' your characters with one poor choice.
* Insane number of loot drops. Even with multiple characters, no one is ever stuck for equipment.
*Four player co-op...c'mon, who doesn't love that?!!
*Local split-screen co-op.  Local co-op is a feature that is missing from way too many game nowadays. Its awesome to have this feature available.
*Levels have a nice varitey of design layouts, encouraging you to employ different strategies. You'll find tactics that work for you no matter what level you are on, but you don't feel like you do the exact same thing for every level.
* Awesome amount of DLC for those who want to keep the game going a bit longer:)
*Being able to change which of your characters you use ingame enables you to play solo if you want to, and you never feel like you are stuck without the defenses you might need.
*Controller support. Having a choice to use controller or keyboard and mouse is great. Both have strong groups of supporters, and its great to have the option that suits your preference.

Cons:
* Rather 'busy' visuals. Hellooo cataracts:)) (kidding). But, the very bright colors, and numbers and icons that constantly appear on screen can be a bit much on the eyes for some. I got used to it, but at first i wasn't sure i ever would.
* enemies have variety, but they lack character. It's hard to pinpoint why i feel this way, because I think it stems from a combination of things.  I hesitate to compare games in a review, but the humorous commentary and cocky swagger of the orcs in Orcs Must Die [by Robot Entertainment] gave the enemies a degree of life that is missing from the enemies in Dungeon Defenders. Also, the slower pacing of the enemies can make you feel like they don't have a sense of urgency. I never really felt that they wanted to destroy that crystal more than anything else in the world.


On the fence:
* Kinda slow pacing. I know I brought up the pacing thing in the cons regarding enemy character, but this element of the pacing regards a different aspect of the game. Everything, from your character to the enemies, seems to plod along quite dreamily. For new players, this can be great, so you have time to react. For more experienced gamers it can be a little frustrating at times.  I can imagine some people dumping loads of 'level up' points into their character just to get him or her to run around a little faster:)
* Local co-op players share loot and currency. For some, its a true chance to cooperate, or it creates a friendly rivalry for cash, and for others a frustrating race to see who can spend the cash to level up weapons and armor first. It depends on who you play with:)) Choose your allies wisely:)
* Story line is almost nonexistent and ultimately irrelevent. Yeah, if you want the story to pull you in and care about the ingame world and the related characters, this game is not for you.
* Cartoony artstyle. Sometimes i like it and other times i wish it was a bit more...mature.

There we go, thats it. These are my thoughts on Dungeon Defenders. So, if after all these years you are still having trouble deciding whether you want to play it...I hope this review helps.

Cheers!

reviewText:
This was amazingly fun with a full group of 4 people when I first started it.  Very fun way to handle the tower defense genre.  There is your standard mage with towers, but also interesting ideas like monk with damage/debuff bubbles, archer using traps for support type defense, and a tanky type knight using walls and ballista.  You can increase either your obstacles' effectiveness, your actual hero effectiveness, or a mix of the two.

It got too difficult to keep up with much of the harder content without getting some amazing gear, which was only obtainable very briefly via some hardcore exploitation.  By the time we got to that point in the content, there was no legit way to get the gear yourself without trading for exorbitant prices.  Was fun while it lasted, and definitely worth some time just to get through the original/non-DLC part of the game to level up and try it out.  Even more so if you've got a group of buddies.

Have not played in a long time so some of the negative aspects may already be addressed by now, but at this point I'm not likely to return.

reviewText:
The greatest and also unique Tower Defense game with the style of a RPG.

Your goal is to defend different crystals in different maps and positions from hordes of enemies, using the building and fighting skills of your character, whose powers increases with the experience they gain while defending, and with the equipments you find scattered around the battlefield. In bigger and harder maps, you may consider getting the support of some friends in order to defend every crystal from the evil, and combining your buildings with different stats or different sets will bring your team to the victory.
If you're playing alone, you may consider to try out all of the four characters, and to use all of their buildings togheter, in order to succeed in the game;
If you're playing with some friends, coordinate each other and combine the different characters's structures in a proper way to have a chance against the wave.

If you're going to buy this game now, be aware of one thing: there are lots of DLCs that adds more playable characters, maps, a new difficulty, and the final part of the story of this game. This means that, without buying almost every DLC, you will have only half of the fun from this game, making yourself consider buying the whole Dungeon Defenders Collection.

Also, if you're going to play huge maps with some buddies, your friends may experience big lags, even if they have a good computer which can normally handle very huge games, making their match boring and stressful.

Though this is a magnificent game, you'll need to shell out a lot of money to really enjoy it; also the developers are no longer working on this game (instead they are in the sequel of this, a MOBA genre), so the lag problems and such won't be fixed.

Buy it at your own risk.

reviewText:
Yep, aware this game is almost 3 years old:)) But I'm gonna write a review anyway! Dungeon Defenders is a choice game:) Recommend? Certainly yes. If hybrid hack and slash /tower defense is your thing then this is for you. If its not, get it any way. You'll still have a blast, especially if you play with mates. I, and everyone I have played with, have had a lot of fun with this game.

The following is a list of what I consider pros, cons, and things I am on the fence about . Pros being things i liked (of course), cons being things that annoy me, and 'on the fence' being things that are kinda  'hmmm...yeah, mehh' but not enough to sway my opinion of the game. And yes, my opinion is subjective:) Here we go:

Pros:
* Multiple characters to choose from with distinct abilities. Allows for a variety of play styles. You'll find a character who has a play style that you like and feel 'at home' with.
* Frequent character 'level ups'. Creates a good sense of character progression and hey,  we all love becoming more awesome:)
*'Level Ups' are well balanced. 'Level ups' on both equipment and characters feel like they are a real choice that impacts your play. But not game changing enough that you 'gimp' your characters with one poor choice.
* Insane number of loot drops. Even with multiple characters, no one is ever stuck for equipment.
*Four player co-op...c'mon, who doesn't love that?!!
*Local split-screen co-op.  Local co-op is a feature that is missing from way too many game nowadays. Its awesome to have this feature available.
*Levels have a nice varitey of design layouts, encouraging you to employ different strategies. You'll find tactics that work for you no matter what level you are on, but you don't feel like you do the exact same thing for every level.
* Awesome amount of DLC for those who want to keep the game going a bit longer:)
*Being able to change which of your characters you use ingame enables you to play solo if you want to, and you never feel like you are stuck without the defenses you might need.
*Controller support. Having a choice to use controller or keyboard and mouse is great. Both have strong groups of supporters, and its great to have the option that suits your preference.

Cons:
* Rather 'busy' visuals. Hellooo cataracts:)) (kidding). But, the very bright colors, and numbers and icons that constantly appear on screen can be a bit much on the eyes for some. I got used to it, but at first i wasn't sure i ever would.
* enemies have variety, but they lack character. It's hard to pinpoint why i feel this way, because I think it stems from a combination of things.  I hesitate to compare games in a review, but the humorous commentary and cocky swagger of the orcs in Orcs Must Die [by Robot Entertainment] gave the enemies a degree of life that is missing from the enemies in Dungeon Defenders. Also, the slower pacing of the enemies can make you feel like they don't have a sense of urgency. I never really felt that they wanted to destroy that crystal more than anything else in the world.


On the fence:
* Kinda slow pacing. I know I brought up the pacing thing in the cons regarding enemy character, but this element of the pacing regards a different aspect of the game. Everything, from your character to the enemies, seems to plod along quite dreamily. For new players, this can be great, so you have time to react. For more experienced gamers it can be a little frustrating at times.  I can imagine some people dumping loads of 'level up' points into their character just to get him or her to run around a little faster:)
* Local co-op players share loot and currency. For some, its a true chance to cooperate, or it creates a friendly rivalry for cash, and for others a frustrating race to see who can spend the cash to level up weapons and armor first. It depends on who you play with:)) Choose your allies wisely:)
* Story line is almost nonexistent and ultimately irrelevent. Yeah, if you want the story to pull you in and care about the ingame world and the related characters, this game is not for you.
* Cartoony artstyle. Sometimes i like it and other times i wish it was a bit more...mature.

There we go, thats it. These are my thoughts on Dungeon Defenders. So, if after all these years you are still having trouble deciding whether you want to play it...I hope this review helps.

Cheers!

reviewText:
An awesome mix of tower defense and action-RPG.

The tower defense and action-RPG aspects blend wonderfully, as there are class and character building choices for every sort of player. Someone who is more akin to setting up a line of defenses could pick the Apprentice (a very strong defensive structure class) and put their skills into making their defenses better. Someone who wants more action and wants to kill enemies themselves could pick the Huntress (fantastic dps class) and put their skills into making their character's stats better.

Although you play the same missions a lot of times over, they manage to be dynamic with different difficulty levels, very unique classes, and the billions of possible equipment options.

The only major flaws I've encountered with this game are disconnections from the online play server and disconnections from hosts themselves; however, Trendy's been working hard to get this stuff fixed.

This game is amazing and I recommend it as a must buy.

reviewText:
For the initial price, Dungeon Defenders (DD) provided way more value for your money than most games.  If they had stopped there, the game would have been insanely popular.

But they started releasing tons of 'tweaks' that changed things by (usually) 30-40%.  Changes on such a scale are a bad idea, and quickly unbalanced everything.  Months later, the changes now seem to be fairly stable...  If it weren't for all the DLC.

See, the DLC tends to add further unbalancing changes.  And the cycle continues, over and over.

Buy this game for the original content, and try not to be disturbed by the changes.  It's immensely fun.

And if you buy the DLC, expect it to be horribly unbalanced.

Also, bring friends, or play solo.  PUGs in this game are the worst ever.

I got bored with Last Stand Mode in Dawn of War 2: Retribution a year ago, this game reminds me a lot of that, but it is quite a bit nicer. Dozens of different maps, many different classes to play (Four come standard, the rest is DLC) and each of them has it's own niche role. Today I started an Apprentice, and after getting him to a basic level in single player, went to do a MP campaign on Hard difficulty. Then suddenly a level 100 Sorcerer named Dumbledore joined the game and carried me through the entire thing. At the end I was level 56. I find it quite amazing that a principal can find the time to run a school, and still help aspiring sorcerers with their levelling.

All in all the levelling is not grindy, and the characters are all cool in their own way, except the Jester, who seems to poop out ogres with 100k HP in Easy difficulty games where  it will squash all the sub-level 30 players in it's path since their DPS does not even break a thousand. That said, Shreck is love, Shreck is life.

Really good tower defense game with a hero as a main character. It plays much like an RPG game with tower defense elements which are combined in a very interesting way. Same for towers, they can attack them which is rather unusual for a tower defense game. Only annoying till you adapt to this.

Other two things that i also don't like is the loot management, in later games you get so much items after every wave it's ridiculous and even though there is a yay and nay system with a thumb icon, it's still jolly overwhelming and difficult to manage. So i basically just used 2 staff weapons that i felt have good stats and i upgraded that. Similar for the rest.
Second thing is, the game is rather short and the rest of the stuff you think you have turns out to be just tons and tons of DLC stuff that you have to pay. Even half of friggin challenges. Not cool.

Despite what it seems like a lot of negative things about it, it's still a good game that i'd recommend, just be aware that not everything you see in the menus is playable. So you won't be disappointed afterwards. Had quite some fun, so yeah, still recommended.

reviewText:
For the initial price, Dungeon Defenders (DD) provided way more value for your money than most games.  If they had stopped there, the game would have been insanely popular.

But they started releasing tons of 'tweaks' that changed things by (usually) 30-40%.  Changes on such a scale are a bad idea, and quickly unbalanced everything.  Months later, the changes now seem to be fairly stable...  If it weren't for all the DLC.

See, the DLC tends to add further unbalancing changes.  And the cycle continues, over and over.

Buy this game for the original content, and try not to be disturbed by the changes.  It's immensely fun.

And if you buy the DLC, expect it to be horribly unbalanced.

Also, bring friends, or play solo.  PUGs in this game are the worst ever.

reviewText:
A strong and diverse tower defense game with a RPG twist in the form of leveling and gear, Dungeon Defenders is a solid experience for the money. The story is your typical fantasy trope, but it’s hardly impedes play enough to bog you down. The small stable of characters is diverse with each class engaged in their own building with powers and towers, injecting an interesting amount of variety (and strategy) to each of the colorful levels. The game is littered with achievements and rewards to earn from each successful completed area. The Inn as a home base for all of your trophies is a spectacular touch, adding a virtual boasting for the competitor in us all.

There are a few drawbacks, though. The online element is your typical mixed bag with instances alternating between super awesome to loathsomely awful; a strong set of online friends will improve your experience.  The endgame numbers grind is another flaw that hits the fun factor like a ton of metaphoric bricks, but by the time you get to that point, you’ve well gotten your money’s worth.

Overall, Dungeon Defenders is a quaint tower defense game with enough fresh angles to make it worth the journey.

reviewText:
Dungeon Defenders - Your everyday tower defense game.

There is a very big reason why I recommend this game - It is possibly the only game that my wife and I can play together without going at each other throats.

The background (story - if you can even call it that) is quite simple. The heroes go away for blood and glory, leaving the apprentices behind. As any proper apprentice does, they messed up and now hordes of orcs are invading you from every corner to destroy the Eternia Cristals and unleash a new latent evil).

So long story short - you have a cristal and you have to defend it at all cost.

The positives:
+ Very fluid game
+ Different Classes with unique traps and tricks
+ Nice cartoonish characters
+ Smooth Learning curve
+ Can be amazingly challenging, depending on how you play it
+ Nice to play with friends and family

The negatives
- Can be repetitive (after 60h of game I am still loving it, but I can understand why people would say that)
- Very segmented in DLCs. It is frustrating when you realize that you only have 50% of the game, and the other 50% is in DLCs.
- Playing on-line with strangers is not very fun. Strangers dont tend to play as a team and the game becomes more a race to see who plants more of their own traps. Furthermore, higher levels will have no trouble outshining the lower level players.

My personal experience:

I have 2 characters - one in which I have been using to play alone (full single player, without even mixing classes) and other that I use to play with my wife.

My experience as single player - From what I read - and from what I believe it is the way the game was built to be played, when going single - you should use several characters and combine their traps in the most efficient way. Personally speaking, I have found extremely fun and challeging only using one character and its own abilities/traps. And trust me - it is hard, challenging, and sometimes it even seems impossible.

When I am playing with my wife - we often spend time discussing where and when to place traps in the latter maps, and we are already working as a well oiled machine in the maps that we know better. We have been able to evolve characters +\- at the same time, and it is nice to see that even though we use different classes, we both feel that our roles as individuals and as a team are important to beat the level.

I feel that evolving the characters at a simillar rate has helped improving the fun of the game. If you have a couple of close friends that commit to level their characters at the same pace as you guys, everybody will feel important during game play and everybody will draw the most fun of it.

Just a personal opinion, but this is a game I would definitaly recommend, either if you are playing single or multi with close friends.

reviewText:
Edited a finalized copy of my review 3/26/15 after first playing and experiencing the game in 2011.

Dungeon Defenders commonly abbreviated in shorthand notation as DD is a action roleplaying, Indie, tower defense & strategy game. It has leveling , gear, pets, loot, tower defense and everything else. It really does have it all.

The most addictive game I have ever played in history of gaming. Also the game I have spent a nearly impossible amount of hours I never thought I would get to. I am a veteran that played this game for three years off an on very heavily. In the summertime I was a regular, many times in college too I became a regular that would endlessly farm the dreaded map known as Lab Assault for the best gear and pets in the game; end-game farming.

Let's breakdown the game and the cons and positives I see:

Gameplay: Gameplay is nonetheless the perfect combination of simplicity, a balance between reward over much longer periods of time to keep gamers hooked and always coming back for more. This game is meant to be played in four player co-op online with friends. It is a hardcore game that is setup like a MMO rather because of the grindy xp from the gap from level 90 to level 100 which by my caculations if you normally get it the fastest and easiest way doing a map called Tavern Defense on the hardest difficulty being NM hardcore it would take 10+ hours per character to get level 90 to max level 100 if starting from level 1 powerleving your character. I base this caculation based off of the 1.5 billion xp it takes to hit level 100.

Hackers are present alot online on ranked. That is why if you trade on the official DD forum or from other trustable users make sure to visit the forum and put your items in the item check thread to get precise clarity that all the items you have are indeed possible and legit.

From my own personal experience this game made me come back again and again to master what I had already achieved over and over again until I pretty much mastered every single NM map out there with a few exceptions such as Winter Wonderland, Crystalline, Planitir & Aquanos. All the rest I mastered for the fairest part.

The other factor that led me to keep coming back is helping others. Those brand new in the game and then those that I found through hosting online pubs and friending online. I never minded powerleveling alot of users for it was my pleasure to do so.


Balance and Reward system: To be honest the game's system is exactly like gambling. Some days you wil come home and win big while other days when farming for the best gear and weapons you will receive trolled stats with some important and key stats missing or just others that do not cap when you hope they will. This is a large part of the reason why so many users spend hundreds of hours farming on this game because the reward system does not come without a full out dedication and pursual to grind it out daily and weekly if you want the best of the best.

Yes, I have at least 2500 hours of non-afk time of gameplay in this game. I can remember that I bought this game shortly one month after it was released on PC. It instantly had me hooked after the first three hours. So much where the next day it became five to six hour sessions and continued and continued until I eventually obssessed over just stats, cosmetics, and event items. If you don't believe me then feel free to check out my steam profile and some of the collection of 950+ screenshots of this game I have taken over the years. I have all dlc with the exception of two costume packs by the way.


Controls: Mouse and keyboard controls work best for this game. Control movements are quick and fluid. I wish I could say the same about my DDE cheap impulse buy but I can't lol. Controls and camera are very agile and keeps a good drive and feel even when there are thousand of enemies in a wave at a time.

DLC: Majority of the dlc is new maps, new characters and the increased level cap when you unlock nightmare mode by purchasing the Eternia Shards Complete DLC. Many characters such as the jester, barbarian, summoner and series EV you will want because they all give you an advantage to improving your building, reinforcing your defenses and then increasing your overall best dps. Jester ups your defenses faster then any other character can while the summoner has seperate defenses then other characters; he can stand in one spot and just summon across the whole map without moving. Series EV buffs your defenses so you survive in NM mode essentially. All these characters are very important for nightmare mode.

Replayability factor: Here is a con of mine I will always have. After you have completed all the achievements, maps on all difficulty modes, all challenges and gotten past 5k builders ; maybe up to 6k and higher for builders and some dps characters then there really is not much point to trying to grind for the absolute best gear which has like a 1.7% drop rate.

Gear rarities and sets:  You have armor sets you get by collecting pieces of the same type of armor. They are listed in the form of level required. godly, mythical, trans, supreme, ultimate and finally ultimate + and ultimate ++ gear which is hard as hell to endlessly grind for like your gambling almost.

Lastly, I normally would not recommend this game to majority of people beause of the time investment in takes to keep up with other people in game, the addictive tendencies of a flawed balance and reward system for gear where to create new sets without trading it could take ten's to hundreds of hours depending on how far you want to go.

Finally this was the first game that started an obsession past the basic grounds of video game addiction for me for three years.I tried to quit this game about six times and just could not force myself to put it down. I went past what most players would do consisting of me running a map running service for a quick map I mastered doing 880 runs in two weeks time which took me more than a hundred hours to get capping ult sets and double cap diamonds which are some of the best higher gear in the game other than ult+ and ult++. I had a few capping ult+ through trading here and there too lol.

The story goes that I gave all this legit gear to one of my friends so then I could take a three month break from steam fully. I deleted then all 299 of my friends I met through playing DD online. Let me remind you this is after that summer where my save files all got corrupted and I started from scratch. I releveled since then six new maxed out level heroes ; got the rare Bunny squire costume lol and did that service for the community before my final departure with the game. Overall I had eighteen max level characters if you count twelve on my original characters that got deleted when my save files got corrupted and all my game data got lost. Six max level heroes combined with backup builders and heroes non-max level after I started back from scratch.


All in all for the sake of this review I will recommend it. Just a warning: Be wise and do not carelessly lose sense of obligations, refuse to hang out with friends, loss of social life, refuse to hear what family has to talk about and then donate 120 or more hours with two weeks time to this game repetitively. Like I say I was obssessed with this game ; so much to where I couldn't get past my obsession for at least a good two years.

Yet as I am writing this review I still flock back on the game every so often just to see my bunny squire. What does that say about me when I love my bunny squire costume so much sometimes I just play some maps with friends or help people out to see my bunny character again with his backpack of eggs?

reviewText:
Dungeon Defenders adds a new twist to tower defense with a mishmash of RPG, action, and tower defense gameplay elements making for a worthwhile investment. There is plenty of content to keep players busy – whether it be working their way through the campaign and tackling challenges. It’s not with its setbacks, though, with the less-than-exciting combat system and loot that feels more like a chore than a reward system.

Tower defense sits at the heart of Dungeon Defenders. The player takes on the role of a Squire, Apprentice, Huntress, or Monk using traps, barricades and magic to defend the castle from an army of evil creatures these would-be child heroes have mistakenly unleashed. Each level plays out in an arena with several entry points for enemies to spawn from. It is the player’s job to analyze the level map and exploit choke points with barricades and traps to prevent enemies from destroying the Eternia crystal at the center of the map. The game is played from the third-person perspective, requiring characters to traverse the map to set up towers while battling enemies along the way.

Enemies are varied and numerous, requiring different strategies to counter their abilities. Hulking orcs will devastate defenses, mages heal enemy units, and suicidal kobolds rush towers with dynamite strapped to their backs. Minibosses in the form of giant ogres made us rethink our tower placement in several situations and the major bosses present the biggest challenges in the game.

Dungeon Defenders has all of the workings of the standard RPG fused into the tower defense gameplay. Player classes have unique abilities, armor, weapon types, and towers. Killing enemies, conquering campaign levels, and completing challenges earns experience which unlocks abilities and towers as well as more powerful items. Character and tower attributes can be upgraded with points earned upon leveling through a somewhat confusing menu system – improving maximum health, damage, casting speed, and movement speed, among others.

All of these features add a great deal of replayability to the game – as does the multiplayer. Once we worked through the levels and beefed up one character, we wanted to level up a complementary character to make proper use of the character swap feature and get the upper hand on some of the more difficult challenges. Setting up spiked barricades as the Squire and switching to the Apprentice to place projectile throwing magic towers makes for a devastating combination. It feels great to level up a character, unlock the advanced towers, and add them to your defense strategy. Playing with a friend or three adds a new dimension in strategy as we were required to actively communicate in tower placement, mana distribution, and repair efforts to hold back the onslaught. The real fun comes in joining a party of friends to tackle the hardest challenges and picking up epic loot.

Unfortunately the action aspect of gameplay falls short. The combat became stale very quickly. Although the characters have special abilities like the Squire’s spin attack or the Huntress’ invisibility, we rarely found a need to use them. Enemies were easily dispatched with well-placed towers and planning trap layouts and developing strategies was fun, but jumping into the fray was not – especially with the melee characters. Combat essentially involves mashing on the one attack button and maybe throwing in a special ability for kicks. Neither feels particularly effective and leaves the combat feeling shallow.

Another problem we had with Dungeon Defenders was the loot. Items can be found in treasure chests and is also dropped by enemies. Picking up epic new armor or weapons and equipping them to benefit from their attribute bonuses is a strong motivator to up the difficulty on the challenges, but the problem lies in having to sort through piles and piles of useless loot at the end of a wave. Checking each dropped item’s stats to compare to our equipped set slowed the game down considerably since all of the loot is spread across the map and it takes at least a few seconds to inspect an item. While we could just run through the map and throw everything into our item box to review later, having fewer, more useful drops would have kept loot gathering from becoming such a chore.

Dungeon Defenders is a worthwhile addition to your game library with plenty of content for the price. Although the combat falls short, the tower defense gameplay, RPG elements, and the challenging game modes will have fans of tower defense delighted.

reviewText:
Reviews for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing

With regard to accessibility for deaf/hoh gamers, I give Dungeon Defenders an 8/10.

Gameplay
There appear to be visual cues to most (if not all) events in the game. The screen does get very cluttered, though, and it can become easy to miss a key visual such as your crystal being attacked, which can lead to losing a game. This event is accompanied by a sound for HOH gamers.

Subtitles/Text
Dungeon Defenders has a storyline that plays in cutscenes. When you turn captions on, the cutscenes will be the only time that you see the subtitles, as the gameplay does not require them.

Chatting/Communicating
Dungeon Defenders has voice chat. In my experience so far, most people do not seem to use it, though, and prefer to type. There are no key combinations or voice binds to convey messages quickly, so you will need to type if you cannot hear/speak.

Dungeon Defenders is a quirky little game where, on top of being a tower defense, you also have to run around and shoot things. Ever played Sanctum 1 or 2? Then keep your money, bud, cause this is just a less fun version.

The basic premise is you four heroes in training must hold the line against invading waves of heroes while the real heroes are out gettin donuts or somethin. I didn't pay attention to that bit. So you build turrets and collect resources dropped from chests and enemies to build turrets or to upgrade your abilities and weapons. In the end we have an tower defense third person shooter with rpg elements. It's got a cute little cell shaded graphic style that I can't help but find appealing and honestly the actual mechanics of it all aren't half bad if you can excuse the fact that projectile attacks are virtually useless if not awkward as a 14 year old trying to talk about his sexual experiences in a positive light. Yeah I bet you got it good last night, Uncle Paul.

So why not reccomend it? BECAUSE IT'S BOOOOOOOOORING. Honestly, the game is so unbelievably slow paced. Everything is slow, the enemies are slow, the projectiles are slow, the turrets are slow, every attack is slow and boring and lame. I'd call it a childrens game, but Kameo: Elements of Power was a childrens game and on the hardest difficulty can at least keep you paying attention. You know what else is a childrens game? The Legend of Zelda. A game that isn't combat orriented still has far superior combat mechanics and faster paced gameplay then a game that boasts it.

On top of the slow game play, it's just plain awkward. Projectile attacks can hardly be called skill shots, since the move barely any faster than the enemies and you never run out of amunition. Only the mage and the knight are really worth anything because the knight can literally just stop an entire wave with two turrets and shell them with cannonballs that are basically 2 hit kills on large enemies. The monk supposedly has healing abilities but there's never any need because you have to actually try to die in this game.

Simply put, it's boring. It's cute, it's quirky, it's unique(kinda), but it's just too slow. It's upgrade system is just a massive min/maxfest and leaves so much to be desired.

Should you buy it?
Do you play EVE online? Yes? This game is gonna be too slow even for you.

reviewText:
It's hard to put into words what genre this game is or really what the game is.  It has RPG elements, strong tower defense elements, and some MOBA/DOTA style elements.   It's also an amazing and fun game.

You'll have access to four unique classes initially, though DLC unlocks a number more.   Each has their own play style for not just their towers but also their actual fighting.   This means you can enjoy a lot of replay value out of it, as you find different ways to beat the various maps on the higher difficulties with different kits.

Additionally, you can swap characters between waves of enemies.  So once you grow your character pool, you can solo content on difficulties you would normally want a group for by just setting up defenses as a wider spread of classes.

I've sank around 220 hours into this game and had a blast playing it.

reviewText:
Greetings defenders or potential defenders,

I really enjoyed this game. It is one of my favorites.
You are a little hero like an apprentice, knight monk or huntress and have to defend the Eternia Crystals from the evil force in level-based towerdeffense roleplay. The mechanics and uniqueness of each hero and the combination of all are the key to victory. For example, the kobolds are running straight to your crystal and you have an apprentice and your friend a monk. You can easily build a blockade to buy time for the monk to summon an electric aura which shocks the kobolds to death. Well done little hero!
With killing enemies and winning levels you can earn weapons or armor, which ups the damage of your electric aura or the durabilty of your spike blockades. Also your character can level up to become stronger. To make it a solo game too, you have before every wave a build phase, where you can build your towers and change to other characters, but the game is best played with a friend. For all who do not have one, you can also join random games or search in the community for friends.

My biggest problem with the game is the fact, that the game can not played that good without DLCs. While some DLCs just add new characters and levels, some of them are needed to get some levels, so i would buy just the original game or directly all DLCs, so you really know, that you do not buy something you cannot reach without annother DLC. Another good fact about the producer studio is, that EVERY dlc is free for the fist 2 weaks after publication and that is definitly a thing you should support with buying this game.
All in all I really recommend this game to all RPG and Towerdeffense fans, because it combines both genres perfectly in an awesome comic style game with a nice community and a modding system.

reviewText:
I used to play a lot of Tower Defense maps when I played Warcraft III. (both Reign of Chaos and Frozen Throne) I found it highly entertaining, yet it sometimes became repetitive with the snap-to-grid build locations. A few years have passed since I last touched Warcraft III, but my love for Tower Defense games never faded. I would always have at least one or two on my iPhone.

Then one day I met Dungeon Defenders.

Not only do you have the freedom to build your towers or traps nearly everywhere on the map; you have your own Hero that you can control and engage in combat. Each Hero has their own types of Towers and Abilities, making the fun for a wide variety of people. The best part of this game is, you don't have the fight the waves of monsters alone. You can bring 3 friends with you to defend the Eternia Crystals. I highly recommend this game, even if don't know much about Tower Defense, because you can spend your skill points on your Hero itself, instead of the towers.

Always be sure to look at some gameplay before you consider purchasing, it can make or break your decision to buy it.
